message.content: Yes, the authors describe the limitations of their work in the "Limitations and broader impact" section. They mention that their definition of the usefulness of an explanation is quite general and discuss two key limitations associated with their approach: 1) it does not take into account the level of machine learning expertise of the user, and 2) the need for human participants to evaluate explanations brings challenges compared with the automated metrics currently used in the field.

Yes, the authors describe the limitations of their work in the "Limitation and broader impact" section. They acknowledge that their definition of the usefulness of an explanation is quite general and point out two specific limitations associated with their approach: 1) it does not take into account the level of machine learning expertise of the user, and 2) the need for human participants to evaluate explanations brings challenges compared with automated metrics currently used in the field.

Yes, the authors describe the limitations of their work in the "Limitation and broader impact" section. They discuss two primary limitations of their approach: the fact that their approach does not take into account the level of machine learning expertise of the user, and the challenges associated with human participants evaluating explanations compared to automated metrics. They acknowledge these limitations and express their hope that by releasing their data and software, they can encourage further evaluation and development of explainability methods.
